title: EY, PwC fly, dine and accommodate ATO officials at conferences
text:
EY also sponsored a series of trips that included accommodation, flights and hospitality for a conference in Singapore in May last year. The value of the trip is described only as being more than $200.

Big four rival PwC paid for another official's travel and accommodation to its global conference on large corporate tax in Paris in July. The value of the trip is not disclosed on the register.

Law firm King & Wood Mallesons paid more than $200 for drinks with the ATO, the Australian Government Solicitor and the Sydney tax bar in February last year. The register says the number of attendees is not known.

Professional bodies the Tax Institute and the Institute of Public Accountants also have hosted ATO officials regularly for conferences and professional development events.

The Korean Institute of Public Finance paid for airfares and accommodation for a trip last month to "assist Treasury and improve relations with other tax administrations".

ATO officials were sent to "learn from Korea and other countries attending the conference". The cost is not listed on the register.

Items referred for display, storage, donation or disposal by the ATO included a box of 12 bottles of wine from the South Australian Tax Institute chapter, an iPad Pro and a smart watch won as lucky door prizes.

Other gifts that were declined included a bottle of French champagne, two sponsored trips listed as study tours to Silicon Valley and accommodation at a luxury Sydney hotel.

Advertisement

ATO officials are required to disclose any gift or hospitality worth more than $200, whether they accept or decline it.

The Public Service Act and the Public Governance Performance and Accountability Act require government employees to avoid both real and apparent conflicts of interest.

Guidance from the Australian Public Service Commission requires public servants to "always be cautious about accepting hospitality from private-sector service providers", especially when it has a significant monetary value.

An ATO spokesman said the organisation was committed to a transparent, sensible and accountable process for gifts, hospitality or other benefits.

"We encourage our staff to politely decline any offers of gifts or hospitality if this can be done without causing offence," the spokesman said.

"We do not require our staff to declare a token gift of negligible value – for example a simple morning tea or modest lunch when attending a work-related conference or benefits that are generally available to other members of the public.

"ATO employees must consider any conflict of interest before accepting a gift, hospitality or other benefit."

The spokesman said the Tax Office was reviewing its rules and policy in relation to gifts and benefits following the publication of updated guidelines for public service departments and agencies.
description: EY has spent $5300 taking an ATO official to Hong Kong for its Asia-Pacific financial services conference, according to a previously private agency internal gifts registry.
